messages.content:
My Forth compiler in x86-32 mode is now 1/2 the speed of `gcc -O3` at a compression benchmark instead of the previous 1/4 because I replaced the `xchg` instruction with 3 `mov`s for the Forth `swap` word. `xchg` was slow because it's atomic so it had overhead. Now I'm trying to make `rot` use ~4 `mov`s instead of 2 `xchg`s.

Current `rot`
```
xchg eax, [ebx]
xchg eax, [ebx-4]
```

New `rot`?
```
mov ecx, [ebx]
mov [ebx], eax
mov eax, [ebx-4]
mov [ebx-4], ecx
```

My question is, should I be thinking about the pipeline and try to do "read, read, write, write" instead of "read, write, read, write"? Can it be done here? I'm trying to reckon how it could be done 😝
:hmm: How does this relate to RISC-V?

It's the most applicable channel. In the past I've talked about ISAs here. In any case, my Forth compiler is due to get another backend. Maybe it'll be RISC-V, but more likely Xtensa because of what I'm working on
to answer this question: you would have to benchmark things properly (`perf` is your friend here to look at microarchitectural events)
considering that modern microarchitectures will try to service that stuff using a load/store buffer
you are likely not going to see any performance changes
[provided that all four instructions are dispatched at the same time]

The machine code generated is really suboptimal compared to what GCC makes. I think the microarchitecture is compensating a lot. I have a feeling when I make a backend for a simper CPU it will perform much worse because there's no cache or multiple dispatch. I'm not sure

What's the best resource to learn about the boot process on a rv architecture from?
I've used multiboot(2) on x86, but i'm unsure about how it would all work with rv
you read the manual of whatever platform you're targeting to boot
Mm, I didn’t realize that rv differs from x86 in that there’s not really a define way to boot and it’s up to each platform
That’s what confused me
to be fair, that is also the case with x86
the only guarantee that you have is that an x86 processor is going to start in real mode and that it will try to run code out of the last 16 bytes of the first segment
after that it is all platform specific
well to me this was a big difference, because i sat down to write my boot code and i just thought to myself "wait, where am i even supposed to put this"
lol
and that would be something dependent for every implementation out there
the spec for the ISA doesn't tell you what to do as far as i can tell

Can anyone provide a detailed guide on switching privilege modes in RISC-V and verifying the process?

For the most part, that is platform specific. To go from a low privilege to a higher privilege you need to trigger an action that results in escalation of privileges. To go from a high privilege to a low privilege you normally perform that action with the proper `xRET` instruction.

vector data processing is more about bus architecture than pipelining
for vector data processing you want to have an extension implemented that actually handles that
and yes, the bus architecture will need to be in service of that extension
the idea being you can do either wide accesses or burst accesses (or both)
and that you have the instructions to back up that access
having a 128 bit bus will not do much when your loads are limited to 32 bits and your ALU is operating on 32 bit words
So the burst mode be best for this, am I getting it right?
not burst mode per se
Se?
"per se" -> "by itself"

```
main:
        lui     a5,%hi(lumpinfo+8)
        lw      a5,%lo(lumpinfo+8)(a5)
```

`lumpinfo` points to a non-half aligned position in practice

this is all looking fine here; you're doing a load byte unsigned, so the address can be byte aligned
besides the `const`ness stuff that is in the code (technically can yield UB) this is breaking aliasing rules
which is most decidedly UB
you have an implicit cast from a `char[]` into a `patch_t*`
your code is basically going `char[]` -> `void*` -> `patch_t*`
this most decidedly breaks aliasing rules
so yes, expect UB
and expect things to break
this is _not_ your compiler's fault
this is bad code

Being in good terms does not guarantee you funding. You probably want to find out exactly what the professor is interested in. Again, hardware security does not necessarily relate to RISC-V. You could target some RISC-V _implementation_ as a test platform for some hardware security research, but you would need to define what the end-goal here is. For example, if you're looking at hardware trojans then you could test whatever framework you're developing on that RISC-V implementation. However, if I am reviewing your publication based on that, then my first question would be "why are you limiting yourself to testing on a RISC-V implementation?" or "why are you focusing on RISC-V instead of doing something more generic?".

messages.content:
you want to use `objcopy` for that
```bash
$ riscv64-elf-objcopy -Oihex -j.text -j.data some_file.elf some_file.hex
```
That is not a GNU extension. That is a call to `libgcc` filling in for the fact that you have no hardware multiplication.
If your code involves or reduces to a multiply, your compiler must issue assembly that performs that multiplication.
Instead of having that functionality hardcoded within the compiler, it is found in `libgcc` instead
That way, your compiler issues a call to some `libgcc` function to do the heavy lifting.

Hi, So RAM or "memory" is stored in 1 byte ate a specific address, Now if you have a 32-bit computer. Now say you use the lw instruction at a address, The  pseudo steps from there on as I understand it is 1)  Load the starting address in address register but also use a adder  for +1,+2,+3 for your 4 address-registers then use those addresses to assemble the correct word. My Question is, 1)Is my understanding mostly correct and 2) How does it assemble the correct word, Just enabling the output on 4 addresses does not really work, from what I can find online this is handled by the LSU, but still hoe. Is there perhaps any good recourses that explains it.
Doing it sequentially is easy but takes longer, is there a way to do it at the same time
yes, make your memory bus multiple bytes wide
by forcing yourself to use an 8 bit memory bus you need your memory controller to a burst transaction to fetch 32 bits
the memory controller can expose itself to the rest of the SoC as having a 32 bit interface
but that means the memory controller has to stall the bus until it has fetched all the data
alternatively, make your memory wider and fetch wide
that way you don't have to deal with the stalling behavior
some of my boards use a 16 bit bus for memory accesses [which yes, it means i have to serialize wider reads]
but my memory controller exposes itself as a 128 bits interface to the bus (the bus itself is designed to be 128 bits wide)
I see, thanks. Thats pretty cool
